top_comment.text: This is the only movie in theaters out of which I've walked.﻿
top_comment.author: AntonDoesMusic

comments.text:
+vladimirhorowitz Didn't waste my time with GI Joe or Resident Evil movies. 
I did go to We're The Millers, but only to humor my mother. I never would 
have gone in the first place.

And, I'm afraid I will have to argue with you on the dubstep being in 
Gatsby. What would you classify the music in the first scene when Tobey 
Maguire's character is invited to Gatsby's mansion? Or the scene with the 
orgy with his friend and those two harlots? Because that is the music to 
which I'm referring.
comments.author: AntonDoesMusic

comments.text:
+AntonDoesMusic There's no dubstep in Gatsby. I'm not sure which "The Room" 
you're talking about (there's several movies with that title), but 
something tells me that it didn't get any Oscar nominations. I'm just 
curious which movies you saw and didn't walk out of. Resident Evil 3? GI 
Joe? We're The Millers?
comments.author: Vladimir Horowitz

comments.text:
+vladimirhorowitz I'd rather watch The Room than watch people do the 
Charleston to dubstep.
comments.author: AntonDoesMusic

comments.text:
I'm curious how often you go to the movies because there's FAAAAAR worse 
movies out there than Gatsby.
comments.author: Vladimir Horowitz

top_comment.text: Also, "The Great Gatsby" isn't the most boring novel ever. "Dracula" was.﻿
top_comment.author: Hereandnow45

comments.text:
Dracula is pretty dull but it is faintly redeemed by Harker's castle 
climbing scene and Gatsby is anything but boring. Try Middlemarch for 
tediousness; you will dream of the chance to watch paint dry. Anything is 
preferable to the most mundane novel ever to achieve "classic" status.
comments.author: Kitty 450

comments.text: I loved the Great Gatsby!
comments.author: Monica Petras

top_comment.text: was anyone else impressed when he passed the cereal to himself or just me?﻿
top_comment.author: Lacks Talent

comments.text:
+Andrew Forpes
 i also notice this
comments.author: InstantLunch BehrSquad

comments.text:
Yeah but if you pay attention you can see the image changing since both the 
cereal and milk move towards the left a bit more
comments.author: Andrew Forpes

top_comment.text:
The Great Gatsby is my very favorite movie. The colors, the story, the 
acting, the visual effects, the scenery, pretty much everything in this 
movie was really well made. That's just an opinion.﻿
top_comment.author: abatum

comments.text:
well i like the lana del ray imput since it was not supposed to be music IN 
the movie but as a movie bagground music (if you know what i am saying :) )
comments.author: NannoAnno

comments.text:
Yeah, I agree with you. The music at some parts like the one you mentioned 
did not fit the time period at all....
comments.author: abatum

comments.text:
+abatum Hmm, yeah, I guess when you look at it that way. It just feels so 
wrong when you watch the movie, both in terms of time and the way they did 
it. In particular, the scene where you see a car driving by with 3-4 black 
people and instantly you get Jay-Z's song full of racial stereotypes. I 
mean, come on. At least make it fit the time period. The lyrics are 
ridiculous in this context.
comments.author: ztrinx1

comments.text:
Yeah, the music at some parts was awful. But I really liked the way they 
combined the 20's music with today's club music, it was a very interesting 
combination.
comments.author: abatum

comments.text:
I agree, they did a great job. There is however one major thing that I 
absolutely hate - the music! Putting Lana Del Ray and Jay-Z is this movie, 
oh man, that really pissed me off.
comments.author: ztrinx1

top_comment.text:
How the hell does he do the parts where he hands stuff over to himself, 
like the box of cereal?????﻿
top_comment.author: Yury Glazman

comments.text:
At first I thought it was editing but now I'm starting to think that 
they're twins
comments.author: Sean Smith

comments.text:
+tinpot1978  i have no idea about terms in videoeditting so i cant tell 
which word i was looking for, or if there even is a word for that. its just 
my uneducated guess of how he could have done it.
and i think that the slow response is even something that makes the videos 
so good. it seems like "both" guys are really apathic, and dont want to do 
the video but have to while cant standing the other one.
yeah it may be because the timing is a bit off, but still its pretty cool, 
and to do everything in one take (per side) doesnt seem easy either
comments.author: John Smith

comments.text:
+John Smith I think the word you are looking for is "masking". Quite simple 
to do really. I would have been more impressed if he'd have planned the 
conversation better with lots of inturruptions, interjections, quicker 
responses, and the timing for him taking the cereal off his other self was 
waaaay too slow.
comments.author: tinpot1978

comments.text:
my guess is he splits the video in two parts, left and right. but the line 
where its split isnt in the middle, but slightly to the right or left. if 
he uses something on the right side the cut is made on the left side so 
that if the object would be where it is when its hand over, it wouldnt 
appear on the left side of the video. so he puts it into the middle, and 
while the object stays there he drags the line to the right of the object 
and takes it after that. so on the right side it is still there after the 
left guy takes it, but since you see the part from the left video you cant 
see it. the same is that on the left the object was there the whole time 
before it gets passed over, but you werent able to see it because the 
middle showed the video of the right part.

i hope that was understandable
comments.author: John Smith

comments.text: movie magic :D

comments.text: Shit that is good

comments.text: oh wait at 1:11 he cuts the clip

comments.text: I KNOW RIGHT!

comments.text: The box never left the table so it would be pretty easy
comments.author: Anthony Felizardo

top_comment.text:
*SPOILERS*
Too Faithful to the book, absolutely fucking not, Gatsby's dad isn't even 
in it.﻿
top_comment.author: nearthe2nd

comments.text:
Nick doesn't matter! He's a tool to facilitate the main character. What the 
whole fucking movie is/should be about: THe GREAT GATSBY
comments.author: Monica Petras

comments.text:
It's called the Great Gatsby for a reason, there shouldn't be any 
information left out about him.
comments.author: nearthe2nd

comments.text:
It's one of the extra scenes, and when I saw it, the directors said they 
cut it out to make it more Nick's story so it wouldn't fall into more 
Gatsby. That's what TGG is… it's supposed to be both Nick and Gatsby's 
story, but at the end of the day, Nick's the one that lives on and it's 
through his POV that we see everything so it makes sense that the directors 
would want to focus on Nick as the main person for the movie.
comments.author: Megan Kerney

comments.text: I completely agree!
comments.author: Monica Petras

top_comment.text: I cringed every time Leo said "old sport" lol﻿
top_comment.author: MsFarzee

comments.text: To be fair to Leo, I cringed every time Gatsby said it in the book.
comments.author: Risa McCullough

comments.text:
I cringed every second of this dreadfully bad movie, but I'm with ya on 
that old sport... that nonsense turned my cringe into a crown... I was 
crowning something fierce.
comments.author: Dingle Barry

comments.text:
I knew that. That's why it made me cringe. It sounded forced as I suspect 
Gatsby should sound.
comments.author: MsFarzee

comments.text:
I felt like that was intentional; the artificiality of it (Gatsby was a 
"self made man") was meant to be obvious and grating if you were paying 
attention.
comments.author: Roger Levy

captions.text:
Okay we gotta talk about The Great Gatsby.
Gatsby? What Gatsby?

The Great Gatsby. The Leonardo Dicaprio movie
that we just saw. We gotta talk about that.

Why?
Because last week we said we were gonna talk

about Iron Man 3, and you derailed the conversation
like you usually do, and people got upset

that we didn't actually talk about the movie.
If you wanna talk about Iron Man 3, then we

can do it. It sucked balls.
I thought you said you liked it. You said

it was awesome.
That was before I actually saw it.

Listen, the twist is terrible, Pepper does
some ridiculous sh*t, and for the second Iron

Man movie in a row, there's like almost no
Iron Man.

I think the ship has sailed on the Iron Man
3 conversation. People don't want to tune

into a Great Gatsby conversation and hear
us talk about Iron Man 3. And the cycle will

continue on and on. We gotta talk about The
Great Gatsby.

Fine but I have the same problem that I had
last week. I mean, I don't want to spoil the

movie for these people. It's opening day!
There are ways to talk about a movie without

spoiling it. Okay? Like, why don't you just
name something you liked.

Okay.
Okay, why don't you try naming something that

you didn't like. I think that's probably easier
for you.

That's a lot easier. To start with, it's too
faithful to the book.

Too faithful to the book?! Too faithful to
the book?! How is that possible?

Baz Luhrmann should have taken more liberties,
man.

"Too faithful to the book?!" I don't think
I've ever even heard of that.

Have you ever read The Great Gatsby?
Yeah, but it was a long time ago. I don't

really remember it very well.
Yeah, well consider yourself lucky. It's boring.

Dude, it's a classic!
Yeah, classically boring. It is the least

exciting book ever. It's the Mad Men of books.
Alright? It may be brilliant, but it's too,

f*cking, slow.
You have the attention span of a five year

old, alright? What else didn't you like? Anything
else?

Tobey Maguire narrates the whole freaking
movie. This is what you do, when you try and

film a book that's in the first person with
tons of narration, and you realize, "Oh sh*t,

I've gotta do lots of voiceover." Why not
just film Toby Maguire, the actor, sitting

on a stool reading the book and call it a
day?

Right, because that would be entertaining
for everyone. Bill the movie as Peter Parker

reads "The Great Gatsby."
Andrew Garfield is Peter Parker, not Toby

MaGuire, and that's like one of the only things
the new Spider-man movie got right.

Alright. Alright. Well, did you at least like
Leonardo Dicaprio? Did you at least think

Leo was good in the movie.
Leonardo Dicaprio was a good Gatsby.

Okay.
He was, you know, he was a good Gatsby. But

was he a great Gatsby? I don't know. He sounds
pretty goofy saying stuff like "old sport."

Everybody sounds goofy saying "old sport."
Even people that lived in the 20's sounded

goofy saying "Old sport." That's, like, the
whole point.

That's a pretty stupid reason to write a whole
book.

Did you at least find the movie visually stimulating
in any way?

Yes, but I found Prometheus visually stimulating.
But I just found the story to be a snoozer.

Great Gatsby the film may look pretty, alright?
But the story's got as much pep as a Model-T.

You can't blame the director for the story!
I can blame him for choosing to adapt this

book into a movie. Yeah, I certainly can.
No one put a gun to his head.

Well, I thought it was great, okay?
Yeah, well you liked Moulin Rouge.

A lot of people like Moulin Rouge.
Well a lot of people are stupid.

You don't have a lot of friends, do you?
The movie's gorgeous, the--

Yeah, until Jay-Z shows up and pulls you right
out of the time period.

That's a stylistic choice, alright? I thought
it was bad-ass. Jay-Z is a lot like Gatsby,

actually.
That's racist.

Not it's not!
Listen why can't you just accept the fact

that some books are unfilmable.
Life Of Pi was supposed to be unfilmable,

right? And then Ang Lee came along and won
an Oscar for it.

Richard Pahkah!
I just walked right into that one, didn't
I?

title: The Great Gatsby - Conversations With Myself About Movies
